channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Macron Returns to Turmoil, as France Weighs State of Emergency
item.media:description: Workers cleaning graffiti off the Arc de Triomphe. Much of it appeared to target Mr. Macron.
item.description: After a summit meeting in Argentina, President Emmanuel Macron surveyed the destruction left after the “Yellow Vest” protests.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Israeli Police Urge Bribery and Fraud Charges Against Netanyahu. Again.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, in Jerusalem last week, has denied the accusations of bribery.
item.description: For the third time this year, the prime minister is accused of corruption. But this time, his governing coalition is already teetering.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: China Dispatch: Epic Battles, Palaces and Concubines: A Chinese Studio’s Vast World of Fantasy
item.media:description: Making a movie in China’s Hengdian World Studios, which claims to be the world’s largest outdoor movie and television lot.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Hengdian World Studios, in a small town in central China, churns out scores of movies and television series from each period in the country’s history.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: A Generation of Widows, Raising Children Who Will Be Forged by Loss
item.media:description: Just months after her husband was killed, Rahila Shams was expecting another child and lay in the early stages of labor with their daughter, Sofia, center, in Kabul.
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.description: The war in Afghanistan is disproportionately killing young men, leaving behind women with limited options.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FATIMA FAIZI

item.title: Egyptian Actress Dressed to Impress. She Could Be Jailed for Debauchery.
item.media:description: Rania Youssef has apologized for wearing a revealing dress at the Cairo International Film Festival.
item.description: Rania Youssef’s lacy, revealing dress at a Cairo film festival spurred three lawyers to sue her. A trial has been scheduled for January.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: In a Divided Bosnia, Segregated Schools Persist
item.media:description: The school in Travnik is a symbol of the ethnic and religious divide in Bosnia’s education system: Children from Croatian Catholic families attend class in the right side of the building. On the left, the students are predominantly Muslim.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: Ethnic tensions are worsening in Bosnia two decades after a bloody, bitter war. The divide is most obvious inside the country’s segregated schools.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe

item.title: Brazil’s New Leader Wants to Ease Gun Laws. Supporters Are Ready, and Training.
item.media:description: Natalia Ortega received instruction from a coach at a shooting club in São Paulo, Brazil, this month.
item.media:credit: Gabriela Portilho for The New York Times
item.description: President-elect Jair Bolsonaro wants to make it easier for “good guys” to own firearms, though most Brazilians think civilian gun ownership should be banned.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: World Leaders Praise Bush as a Calm and Vital Statesman
item.media:description: President George Bush, left, and President Mikhail Gorbachev of Russia in Helsinki, Finland, in 1990.
item.description: From the Middle East to Europe, leaders praised Mr. Bush’s for his political abilities. Officials lauded his dedication to reuniting a post-Cold War Europe.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: U.S. and China Call Truce in Trade War
item.media:description: President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at a dinner meeting at the end of the Group of 20 summit meeting in Buenos Aires.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: In a meeting with President Xi Jinping of China, President Trump agreed to hold off on a plan to raise tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods on Jan. 1.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: John Chau Aced Missionary Boot Camp. Reality Proved a Harsher Test.
item.media:description: John Allen Chau spent time in Port Blair on South Andaman Island before he set off for North Sentinel Island.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.description: Before being killed on a remote island in the Andaman Sea, Mr. Chau attended a missionary training camp in Kansas.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, KAI SCHULTZ, AYESHA VENKATARAMAN and HARI KUMAR

item.title: North Korean Soldier Defects to South, Crossing Heavily Armed Border
item.description: South Korean soldiers guided the defector to safety after finding him walking across the Demilitarized Zone, the South’s military said on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: What Is ‘La Lista,’ Which Controls Migrants’ Fates in Tijuana?
item.media:description: A Mexican woman seeking asylum in the United States presented documents with her son this week at the border crossing in Tijuana, Mexico, after her number was called from The List.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The first all-important step for caravan migrants who come to northern Mexico to seek asylum in the United States is to get on The List.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Albino Pageant Carries a Serious Message
item.media:description: Elsie Lynn, 6, having her makeup done at the Mr. and Miss Albinism East Africa contest in Nairobi on Friday.
item.description: A groundbreaking beauty pageant chose the first Mr. and Miss Albinism East Africa in Kenya’s capital. People with the hereditary condition have faced discrimination, violence and even murder.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Music Festivals Are Gaining Popularity in Asia. Just Not With Officials.
item.media:description: A nightclub in Hanoi in September. Asia is a growing market for Western-style music festivals.
item.description: Conservative governments have been canceling Western-inspired events, which they see as threats to public safety, political stability or social and religious values.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Yellow Vests Riot in Paris, but Their Anger is Rooted Deep in France
item.media:description: Yellow Vest protesters at a roundabout in Vaury, France. They wait in the in the rain and cold and mud under makeshift tarpaulin shelters and tents.
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.description: With little organization, fueled by frustration, the protests have moved from poor rural regions to the banks of the Seine, the scene of riots this weekend.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: The Corruption Cases Against Netanyahu
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arrived for the weekly cabinet meeting at his office in Jerusalem on Sunday.
item.description: The Israeli prime minister faces possible bribery and fraud charges stemming from three separate corruption investigations this year.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Israeli Software Helped Saudis Spy on Khashoggi, Lawsuit Says
item.media:description: A symbolic funeral prayer for the murdered Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul last month.
item.description: A Saudi dissident based in Canada claims the Saudi government planted spyware in his phone to eavesdrop on his talks with Jamal Khashoggi.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: American’s Death Revives Evangelical Debate Over Extreme Missionary Work
item.media:description: Room 121 at Lalaji Hotel, where Mr. Chau stayed in Port Blair on South Andaman Island before he set off for North Sentinel island.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.description: Some evangelicals say John Allen Chau’s push to contact an isolated island tribe in the Indian Ocean was reckless.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: How 3 Actors Overcame Trump’s Travel Ban to Take the New York Stage
item.media:description: From left, Moein Ghobsheh, Yasin Moradi and Ammar Haj Ahmad struggled to obtain visas to the United States to perform “The Jungle” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: Two Iranians and a Syrian were allowed entry to perform “The Jungle,” a play about refugees, after urgings by Sting and an ex-archbishop of Canterbury.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Comey Reaches Agreement With Republicans to Testify Behind Closed Doors
item.media:description: James B. Comey, the former director of the F.B.I., has reached an agreement with Republican lawmakers to testify privately.
item.description: A compromise announced on Sunday would allow him to speak publicly about his testimony and for a transcript to be released in 24 hours, he said.
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: ‘Yellow Vest’ Protests Turn Violent in Paris
item.description: A day after protesters torched cars and damaged buildings in the French capital, President Emmanuel Macron surveyed the damage and weighed imposing a state of emergency.

item.title: Killings of Journalists Show the Bloody Fingerprints of Organized Crime
item.media:description: Friends and family members carrying the coffin of Héctor González Antonio, a journalist who was killed in Mexico in May.
item.description: More than two dozen journalists worldwide have been killed by members of organized crime since the start of 2017, according to a report by Reporters Without Borders.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: U.S. Airstrike Kills Senior Taliban Commander in Afghanistan
item.description: Mullah Abdul Manan, who led the Taliban’s brutal campaigns in southern Afghanistan, was killed as American diplomats push the group to join peace talks.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 125 Women and Girls Seeking Food Were Raped and Whipped in South Sudan
item.description: Doctors Without Borders reported the “dramatic increase” in sexual violence occurred as the women and girls were walking to an aid distribution site in Unity State.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Spain’s Far Right Could Help Oust Socialists in Largest Region
item.media:description: Supporters of Spain’s far-right Vox party celebrating after the Andalusian regional elections on Sunday.
item.description: Voting results in Andalusia were a blow to the country’s Socialist prime minister, who could be forced into a snap general election next year.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: The Airports of the Future Have Arrived
item.media:description: The new Istanbul airport is the largest in the world. But not for long.
item.description: Two of the biggest airports in the world — Istanbul and Beijing — aim to make travel easier and faster for the passengers who use them.
item.dc:creator: ZACH WICHTER

item.title: Global Growth Cools, Leaving Scars of ’08 Unhealed
item.media:description: A textile factory in China. The country’s growth is slowing more than experts anticipated.
item.description: Less than a year ago, every major economy was expanding at once. Now, the slowdown holds the potential to intensify the sense of grievance roiling many societies.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Global Health: ‘From Nothing to Gangbusters’: A Treatment for Sickle-Cell Disease Proves Effective in Africa
item.media:description: A doctor evaluating a young patient with sickle-cell disease at a clinic in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo.
item.media:credit: Junior D. Kannah/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Already used in Western countries, hydroxyurea eased painful episodes in African children with the condition. It also reduced the risk of malaria infection.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Egypt Said to Arrest British Teenager for Military Helicopter Video
item.description: The authorities arrested a 19-year-old British tourist over a video he filmed on his cellphone that showed a military helicopter in the background, his family said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Macron Inspects Damage After ‘Yellow Vest’ Protests as France Weighs State of Emergency
item.media:description: Crowds breached security cordons on the Champs-Élysées in Paris ahead of a third rally against high fuel prices.
item.description: A government spokesman said one option was imposing a state of emergency to prevent a recurrence of the worst civil unrest in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Immigrants Are Entitled to Jury Trial for Deportable Offenses, New York Court Rules
item.media:description: Saylor Suazo, an immigrant from Honduras who remained in the United States after his visa expired, was arrested by federal agents as he left a Bronx courthouse.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: The decision modifies a state law that critics say deprives immigrants of their right to a jury trial for small offenses that could lead to deportation.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: surfacing: Rwandan Women Paddle Into the Male World of Fishing
item.media:description: Zawadi Karikumutima, a 34-year-old mother of two, maneuvers a pirogue on Lake Kivu, while she and members of her fishing cooperative test the catch for the next day’s fishing, near the village of Musasa, Rwanda.
item.media:credit: Holly Pickett for The New York Times
item.description: “Now a woman can say: ‘I can build a house by myself. I can look after my family properly. And even if my husband dies, we can live a better life.’”
item.dc:creator: SHANNON SIMS, HOLLY PICKETT and CLÀUDIA PRAT

item.title: surfacing: Preserving Black American History Through Song in the Dominican Republic
item.media:description: Martha Leticia Wilmore, 90, a descendant of African-American settlers in the Dominican Republic, eats breakfast in her home in the Wilmore neighborhood in Samana. Her book collection is filled with English language books.
item.description: For older community members, ranging in age from 80 to 104, passing down church hymns is a way to teach the youth about their rich and unique history.
item.dc:creator: WALTER THOMPSON-HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Canada Letter: Canada Faces a New Challenge as a Century of Automaking Ends
item.media:description: General Motors employees gathered on Monday at their union hall in Oshawa, Ontario, the day G.M. announced major closures in the United States and Canada.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Both Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Premier Doug Ford of Ontario pledged to help jobless G.M. workers in Canada. But what aid they can truly offer is unclear.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: ISIS Official Known for Caging Foes Is Captured by Iraq
item.description: The captured operative was a midlevel official best known for having paraded captured Kurdish soldiers in cages.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: G-20, Marriott, Immigration: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Missionary’s Killing Reignites Debate About Isolated Tribes: Contact, Support or Stay Away?
item.media:description: A tribesman aiming his bow at an Indian helicopter in 2004, as it flew over North Sentinel Island, home to the isolated Sentinelese.
item.description: There are dozens of communities that continue to live completely off the grid, mostly in the Amazon, where drug traffickers, miners and ranchers threaten them.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Dodging Friends, Chased by Legal Troubles, Trump Navigates G-20
item.media:description: President Trump with other leaders on Friday in Buenos Aires, including President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: At the Group of 20 gathering in Buenos Aires, President Trump declined to meet with his two favorite strongmen, postponed meeting an ally and was preoccupied with the Russia investigation.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and PETER BAKER

item.title: At War: A Marine's Reaction to a Children's Book Prompts an Apology From the Publisher
item.description: In an article for the Times, a former Marine criticized a “choose your own adventure” children’s book set in Afghanistan. A week later, the book’s publisher wrote to him with an apology.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: U.S. Asks, Are You a Terrorist? Scottish Grandfather Gives Wrong Answer
item.media:description: John Stevenson, 70, has said he accidentally declared himself a terrorist on a form devised by the United States Department of Homeland Security.
item.description: John Stevenson, 70, and his wife may have to cancel their New York holiday because of a mistake he made on an online form.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Tear Gas and Water Cannon Hit Belgian Protesters Inspired by France’s ‘Yellow Vests’
item.media:description: The Belgian police used a water cannon on demonstrators during a protest in Brussels on Friday.
item.description: Hundreds of protesters took to the streets of Brussels on Friday, stopping cars and blocking roads as they called for the country’s leader to resign.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: Ukraine, on a War Footing, Looks Westward for Help
item.media:description: Ukraine’s Border Security Force soldiers patrolling along the Sea of Azov, near the port of Mariupol.
item.description: Russia’s attack on three Ukrainian naval vessels only underscores Kiev’s vulnerability, particularly at sea.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Hate Mail and Conversion Advice: Interfaith Couple Caught in Israel’s Fault Lines
item.media:description: Lucy Aharish is one of the few Arab Muslims to have a prominent role in Hebrew-language news in Israel.
item.description: Lucy Aharish, a TV anchor, and her husband, Tsahi Halevi, an actor, deflect condemnation from politicians and angry strangers with humor and song.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Pontius Pilate’s Name Is Found on 2,000-Year-Old Ring
item.media:description: The ring bearing the name of Pontius Pilate was discovered in the late 1960s, one of thousands of artifacts found in the excavation of Herodium, an ancient fortress and palace south of Bethlehem, in the West Bank.
item.description: The piece bearing the name of the Roman official thought to have ordered the killing of Jesus was found decades ago near Bethlehem, but the inscription was revealed only recently.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: The Man Who Brought Weimar Into Germans’ Living Rooms
item.media:description: The writer Volker Kutscher at the premiere of “Babylon Berlin,” a television series based on his Weimar detective novels that has attracted an audience in the tens of millions in Germany.
item.description: With seven hit novels, now the basis of a blockbuster TV show, Volker Kutscher has helped ignite a debate in Germany about whether history is repeating itself.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Trudeau Nudges Trump About Tariffs at Trade Deal Signing
item.description: President Trump, Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau, and President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico spoke at the G-20 summit meeting about the new North American trade pact, which will replace Nafta.

item.title: gender letter: South Korean Women Smash Makeup, and Patriarchy
item.media:description: Before joining “Escape the Corset” this year, Cha Ji-won sometimes spent $700 a month on makeup.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: The movement is called “Escape the Corset.” Plus: Jameela Jamil’s social media campaign against those weight loss teas and remembering Harvey Milk.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: Trump Signs New Trade Deal With Canada and Mexico After Bitter Negotiations
item.media:description: A dairy farm in Rhode Island. Under the agreement, American dairy farmers would be allowed greater access to Canada’s market.
item.description: President Trump appeared with his counterparts Justin Trudeau and Enrique Peña Nieto to approve the United States-Mexico-Canada agreement.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
